discussion.content:
In a converged wireless network, WWAN control is handled by optional modules installed in Cisco Catalysts switches, which places control for WLAN and LAN in the same location. 

In a centralized Wireless network, WLAN control is performed by dedicated Wireless controllers which reside upstream in the Core layer. In this case, the controllers are separate from the physical LAN, so they cannot provide any control over the LAN.

FlexConnect is similar to a Centralized WLAN, with the added ability for the local AP to operate in Autonomous mode if the link to the controller fails. Neither the upstream controller or the local AP can control the physical LAN.

Autonomous mode is a single AP acting as a standalone, and would have no access to the physical LAN.

questions.question_text: A customer has requested a single point of policy enforcement for LAN and WLAN. Which deployment model should be used?
Which interface is used to connect the foreign and anchor controllers?
What interference you will see when conducting a site survey? (Choose three)

discussion.content:
Why AD-HOC is not likely to show up on a site survey:

Wi-Fi Direct is a means to allow convenient peer-to-peer
communication without an AP, while remaining compatible with 802.11 and any nearby
APs. Because it is based on 802.11, Wi-Fi Direct does not interfere with Wi-Fi, but it can
impact it. Wi-Fi Direct increases the channel utilization; as more devices use it
simultaneously, the 802.11 channels may become unusable.
ver 7.6 and beyond show run-config has replaced running-config

questions.question_text: Which CLI command shows the controller configuration in a way that is similar to the way that it is displayed on Cisco IOS routers?

A customer has a corporate SSID that is configured to authenticate against an ACS server to validate client credentials on the corporate SSID. The customer has a firewall logically positioned on the network between the WLC and the ACS server in the network architecture. Which port must the firewall allow to ensure that authentication can occur?

discussion.content:
On all recent RADIUS server implementations, UDP/1812 is the authentication and authorization port, and UDP/1813 is the accouting port. However, in historic RADIUS versions, these ports were different: UDP/1645 for autentication and authorization, and UDP/1646 for accounting.
(https://community.cisco.com/t5/routing/which-port-numbers-are-used-for-radius-accounting-and-radius/td-p/2494536)
also, 1812 is Authentication Port & 1813 Authorization Port
ACS Server = RADIUS = 1812 for External-Authentication Port & 1813-Accounting Port
